awd_titl_txt: Attract, Retain, and Graduate Young LifE Scientists (ARGYLES)
awd_abstract_narration:
The "Attract, Retain, and Graduate Young Life Scientists (ARGYLES)" project at Rivier University will support and engage students majoring in biology as emergent scientists who will contribute to the vitality of the STEM pipeline in the Northeast.  The program will recruit and enroll 10 low-income, academically talented students (five each in two cohorts) and will provide scholarships for four years.  ARGYLES will strengthen the biology community at Rivier and create a feedback loop of confidence and motivation to help students both learn science and identify themselves as scientists, two key criteria for persistence to graduation in STEM disciplines.  The goal of the program will be for 90% of scholars to complete their first two years of the biology program, and 80% will be retained until graduation.  Upon graduation students will either continue to graduate school or find employment in a STEM field.  Recruitment efforts will focus on low-income, underrepresented minority, and first-generation students.  

Through the use of a persistence framework that fosters students' professional identification, confidence, and motivation to succeed, the project will provide an innovative, integrated approach to building community that enables students to be supported by peers, faculty, and other academic resources.  With guidance from a social science researcher from the Department of Psychology and an external evaluator, the project evaluation will examine the effectiveness of these program strategies and will generate evidence that can be used to support sustained programming and propagation to other departments and institutions.  The project will benefit both individual scholarship recipients, but will contribute to shaping Rivier's STEM academic and support systems as the university focuses on building community and promoting global engagement.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Key Outcomes or Other Achievements

Enrollment, Retention, & Graduation

The program aimed to enroll 10 academically-talented, low-income students majoring in Biology.  Awarding scholarships and retaining scholars was a challenge. The focused attention to this challenge has resulted in the awarding and support of eight scholars: five of the scholars successfully graduated in 2021. The second cohort of three scholars successfully graduated in 2022.  

ARGYLES Experience 

Graduating Scholars felt strongly that ARGYLES provided adequate financial support, helped them feel like they belonged to a community of STEM scholars, opened their eyes to what they could do with a degree in STEM, and was fun. In particular, Scholars highlighted career exploration and trips to Canada as being high-points of their ARGYLES Experience. Scholars felt less strongly that ARGYLES helped them prepare for life after graduation (e.g., graduate school and jobs). In fact, one Scholar suggested that post-grad career preparation start as early as freshman year.

Another factor that impacted the ARGYLES experience for both cohorts was in the summer of 2020. During this time we were unable to offer the camp do to the COVID-19 pandemic.  In August of 2020, even though we moved into our new Science and Innovation Center, due to continuing COVID-19 restrictions we were prevented from offering face-to face labs. Students and faculty collaborated to design and conduct virtual labs.

Professional Preparation for STEM Careers 

Four of the eight (50%) graduating Scholars said they plan to attend graduate school, and four of eight (50%) said they will probably/definitely pursue a STEM career outside of healthcare. Two of the eight (25%) plan to pursue a career in healthcare, and another two (25%) are unsure about their post-graduation plans. Although the plurality of Scholars felt confident in their ability to achieve their professional goals, few felt prepared at the time of graduation to achieve these goals. In 2021, Scholars highlighted the Biology Lecture Series as being the most helpful for STEM career preparation. In 2022, Scholars highlighted Biology Club Activities and Biology Club Membership as being the most helpful for STEM career preparation.

Institutionalization 

The COVID-19 pandemic impacted several ARGYLES events. Nevertheless, ARGYLES continued scheduling speakers to expose Scholars to different career options with their STEM (biology and biotechnology) majors. The alumni panel with recent ARGYLES graduates was particularly well-received. In fact, Scholars reported that there are not enough options to connect with other ARGYLES Scholars.  Rivier University plans to continue scheduling speakers as well as the alumni career panel on an annual basis in order to expose its Biology/Biotechnology students to STEM careers.


Last Modified: 08/17/2022
Modified by: Susan E Langlois
